properties.description: Major center of indigo dyeing. Women's cooperative societies controlled production and trade. Adire cloth known throughout region.
properties.historical_context: Abeokuta founded as refuge city in 1830s. Became major textile center by mid-19th century.
properties.source_citation: Johnson, S. (1921). History of the Yorubas, p. 234

properties.description: Ancient dyeing pits (over 500 years old). Men and women both involved in production. Major export center for dyed cloth.
properties.historical_context: Kano was major Saharan trade terminus. Textile production central to economy.
properties.colonial_impact: British colonial tax policies 1903 onwards affected pricing
properties.source_citation: British Museum. West African Textiles Collection (1899.Af.23)

properties.description: Traditional narrow strip loom weaving. Women's guilds controlled production. Prestige cloth for ceremonies.
properties.historical_context: Long tradition of weaving among Yoruba women.
properties.colonial_impact: Competition from imported cloth in early 1900s

properties.description: Women's weaving tradition using vertical looms. Complex geometric patterns.
properties.historical_context: Distinctive Igbo weaving technique passed through family lines.
properties.colonial_impact: Significant decline after WWII due to imported textiles

properties.description: Elaborate embroidery for royal court. Techniques lost after British invasion of 1897.
properties.historical_context: Part of sophisticated Benin court material culture.
properties.colonial_impact: British punitive expedition 1897 destroyed court and dispersed artisans

properties.description: Traditional beadwork for royal regalia and ceremonial objects.
properties.historical_context: Oyo Empire had sophisticated beadwork traditions for centuries.
properties.colonial_impact: Maintained through colonial period but production shifted to tourist market
